response.answer_text: It depends what perspective you have on Trump, as well as what perspective you have on various Roman Emperors. As with most things, and especially when performing a difficult apples-to-oranges comparison, it all comes down to what you want to see. If you’re one of the people who thinks Trump is an absolute demon who needs to die, he’s very much like Caligula or Commodus. They were both raving mad megalomaniacs who were also incompetent at administration. They were both incapable of doing a thing right, despoiled the morals and the honor of their office, and were horrible emperors. From the columns of diehard #NeverTrump-ers, you’ll actually see this sort of comparison a lot in political discussion. Caligula and Trump: Two disturbingly similar despots centuries apart  A statue of Caligula, a Roman emperor to whom many have compared the current US President, Donald Trump But of course, you could take an alternate interpretation that scholars like Mary Beard have endorsed: that Caligula and Commodus were not insane or necessarily incompetent, but merely anti-establishment radicals who wanted to assert themselves in the world. After all, the vast majority of the Roman population loved both of them. Of course the Senators who were being pushed into irrelevance by Caligula and Commodus’s politics would write incredibly slanted and negative histories to destroy their legacies. The comparison between Trump and Commodus or Caligula, therefore, relies on two subjective interpretations. Many see Trump in a different light. If you despise Trump’s morals, personality, and methods, but nonetheless believe he has good policy and does good things, he’s very much like Domitian. Domitian was also an emperor with a serious grudge against old Senatorial authority, and he worked hard to delegitimize the Senate’s position by going about his business without the Senate’s input. However, Domitian was, by most accounts, a fair and competent ruler.  A bust of the Roman Emperor Domitian, to whom many have compared Trump because of their similarities in radical and brazen disregard for old sensibilities Thus, although Domitian was too brash and careless in his treatment of his potential friends and enemies, he was fundamentally a good leader. One might even say that Domitian’s lack of regard for caution and old formalities enhanced his effectiveness. Many make these arguments about Trump; perhaps his temperament is not the most stable and he may not have any respect for the old accepted standard within politics, but he does many good things as President. And if you think Trump is the greatest thing since sliced bread but is just unfairly maligned, he’s very similar to Hadrian. At the time of Hadrian’s rule, many lambasted him for his withdrawal from Mesopotamia for purposes of consolidating Rome’s borders, saying it was an affront to Roman honor and a sign of weakness. Under him, Rome became more inwardly focused, which was generally seen as a bad thing because Rome had always been outwardly focused. However, in hindsight we see that Hadrian did great work to preserve Rome’s stability and ensure it a long existence.  A statue of the Roman Emperor Hadrian, to whom many have compared Trump because both of them have been ascribed as xenophobic The comparison also looks tempting because Hadrian built several defensive walls around the empire to regulate trade and immigration. Many see Trump’s idea for a wall, as well as the tighter immigration and trade policies that “The Wall” symbolically represents, in a similar light. This also includes other things that Trump has done to make America more inwardly focused. They say it is consolidation of the sort that Hadrian orchestrated: ensuring that America is great, stable, and has a long existence. Of course, each of these comparisons is fundamentally flawed in some way. All Roman emperors ruled as absolute autocrats. A leader like Trump in the US has far less latitude to operate than any Roman emperor ever did. Thus, attempting to apply constructs of autocracy to Trump, who leads a democratic republic, is trying to fit a square peg in a round hole. And in our world of slanted journalism, calling someone an autocrat is clearly just trying to imply something about what one should think about that leader: namely, that they hate democracy and the people. In the Roman world, however, an absolute autocrat like Domitian was immensely popular with the people. The American people would never stand for it if Trump were to become a true autocrat, obviously. The Hadrian comparison is also suspect for separate reasons. His walls served very different purposes from Trump’s proposed wall; once one passes the surface level, the comparison loses its validity. In addition, Hadrian was very well-spoken, educated, and a true participant and patron of the arts. Trump is not, by any means, culturally sensible to the same degree that Hadrian was, and though he may be charismatic to some, he can’t compete with Hadrian. In Caligula and Commodus, I think we can find the best comparison. The two were not necessarily bad rulers in the way that the ancient historians wrote them to be; we simply see them through so many layers of bias from our historical sources. There is a lack of other source material from other perspectives, meaning that we can only use limited archaeology and cross-references with other similarly biased sources to try to piece together a good narrative. There is now a lack of unified perspective on their reigns, meaning that we can’t give them coherent portraits. Trump’s tenure in office is set to play out in much the same way in the annals of history, but for the opposite reason. There is not too little information, but rather too much. There are so many different perspectives and it all revolves around what one wants to think. Some see Trump as a demon, some see him as an angel. Even as Trump’s time is still upon us, we see a raging debate. Think of someone like Reagan and how he is still so polarizing almost four decades later. That will be Trump, but perspectives will be all the more divided. Just like with Caligula and Commodus, we may never have a unified perspective on Trump’s time in office. It will all be left to interpretation, and each of us will see what we want to see.

Claudius.  Borne unto a wealthy family, he was wholly disengaged from serving in government for most of his life. Having never held elected office, he instead was concerned with the private sphere, in which he constantly swindled both rich Senators and common Romans by abusing public funds for his own ends, bribing officials and extorting money. He was of mild health for most of his adult life, maintaining an unhealthy-looking complexion that was noticed by many. Nobody expected him to become the person to assume the highest authority in the Roman Empire, “leader of the Free[/Roman] World”. In fact, it was precisely because he had no experience in office that he was not seen as a threat by his companions, and thus avoided assassination in one of the many purges of the time. Caligula, ‘little boots’, the previous emperor, had just been assassinated by the Praetorian Guard when they reportedly found Claudius hiding as a coward behind a curtain. Presumably trading off ‘little boots’ for ‘little hands’, Claudius assumed the office of Emperor in a shock to all of the other far more qualified candidates for the title. Thus, to this foreigner, Claudius seems to be a good companion to Donald Trump. It should be said that this is where they diverge. Claudius successfully invaded Britain, spread Roman control in Anatolia and North Africa and generally was a successful leader. He supported LLLegal immigration (by Romans) and was quite fine with a multicultural society in which nobody was singled out by ‘race’. Mild artistic license

None. There were 95 emperors, give or take, depending on whether you count the Gallic and British usurpers, and whether you include the Byzantine empire (I don’t - considering that a separate empire). Emperors were non-elected, and nearly all were murdered. In fact only a handful died natural deaths. Analogies between democratically elected politicians like Trump and Roman emperors are based more on the biases of the writer than facts. The best modern analogy for the Roman emperor would be mob boss. The system of patronage, the way they operated, and especially the way they were law unto themselves is much more informative.  John Gotti, the modern Roman emperor equivalent (source) If pushed I would suggest Nero but not for the reasons others have suggested. Nero was hated by the aristocracy and beloved by the common people, something very similar to the situation today for Trump. Nero also suffered from fake news: he didn’t fiddle while Rome burned (violins wouldn’t exist for another 1200 years), likely didn’t light his gardens by burning Christians, and helped the ordinary Romans recover from the devastating fire that his enemies would later blame on him. Writers like Suetonius and Tacitus were writing for Nero’s successors, and it was in their best interest to slander the last of the Julio-Claudians for their benefactors. If so it should serve as a warning to the elite: Nero pretenders plagued the empire for generations after his suicide.

Clodius Pulcher. Both were populist demagogs who courted the favor of the lower classes in spite of being the sons of rich men from prominent families. Clodius was known for having numerous debauched affairs including sleeping with his own sister who was married at the time. Though there’s no evidence Trump has actually committed incest he’s made many notoriously creepy comments about his daughter. Pulcher would also abuse and humiliate his political allies and subordinates, including Pompey Magnus whom he dragged around on the ground to humiliate. This is not dissimilar from the many insults we’ve heard that Trump has for fellow politicians and staff. Pulcher was generally considered to be dishonest, nasty, brutish and a bully. He may have even shared Trump’s crude manner of speech, as the name “Clodius” is actually a street-Latin mispronunciation of his real family name “Claudius” which suggests he talked in a sort of crude lower class dialect.

I would have to grant that distinction to Nero. Nero was a man with no moral compass, believed he, himself, was a genius, and had no regard for anyone other than himself. In the days of the Roman Empire, there were virtually no restraints upon what the emperor could do. Nero killed his mother and wife with impunity. He killed his second wife in a fit of rage, kicking her in the belly when she was pregnant. He ordered his best general to commit suicide. In the modern U.S. the President does not have the same sort of power that a Roman emperor did, so Trump really couldn’t shoot someone on 5th avenue and lose none of his support, but in terms of pure egotism narcissism and total lack of empathy, the personalities of Trump and Nero are very similar.

I’m going with Galba. Basically he was an old man who was a political outsider and no one expected him to become emperor. When he arrived in Rome and took up power he essentially flouted imperial customs and refused to acknowledge practices of previous emperors. This included failing to pay a donative to the Praetorian Guard upon his ascension to the purple therefore ensuring his ultimate downfall. In the end he was quickly usurped and murdered by his successor Otho (should have paid those Praetorians) and ultimately left little to no legacy besides being the first of the four emperors in the year of the four emperors.
